module.p:
Numeric quantity expressions are quantity expressions involving a specific number of things, eg.
Cia mheud chon a tha aig Màiri? How many dogs does Mary have?
còig coin five dogs
dusan cù a dozen dogs
ceud cù agus a h-aon a hundred and one dogs
còrr agus deich coin more than ten dogs

Partitive versions of these numeric quantity expressions are –
Cia mheud de na coin a tha aig Màiri? How many of the dogs does Mary have?
a chòig de na coin ?? five of the dogs
dusan de na coin ?? a dozen of the dogs
ceud de na coin agus a h-aon ?? a hundred and one of the dogs
còrr agus deich de na coin ?? more than ten of the dogs
Numeric quantity expressions contrast with non-numeric, generic quantity expressions.

The most basic kind of numeric quantity expression expresses an exact numeric quantity, for example using a numeral –
Tha aon chù aig Màiri Mary has one dog
... dà chù ... ... two dogs
... trì coin ... ... three dogs
...
... deich coin ... ... ten dogs

Exact numeric quantities between 11 and 19 can be expressed by adding the numeric adjective deug -teen –
Tha aon chù deug aig Màiri Mary has eleven dogs
... dà chù dheug ... ... twelve dogs
... trì coin dheug ... ... thirteen dogs
...
... naoi coin dheug ... ... nineteen dogs

For larger numeric quantities, we can use the numeric nouns –
Tha dusan cù aig Màiri Mary has a dozen dogs
... fichead cù ... ... twenty dogs
... ceud cù ... ... a hundred dogs

Multiples of numeric nouns can be expressed by combining them with the ten numerals –
Tha trì dusan cù aig Màiri Mary has three dozen dogs
... dà fhichead cù ... ... forty dogs
... ochd ceud cù ... ... eight hundred dogs

More complex examples involve conjoining numeric quantity expressions using agus –
Tha fichead cù agus a trì aig Màiri Mary has twenty-three dogs
... fichead cù agus a trì deug ... ... thirty-three dogs
... ceithir fichead cù agus a naoi deug ... ... ninety-nine dogs
... naoi ceud cù deug, ceithir fichead agus a naoi deug ... ?? ... nineteen hundred and ninety-nine dogs

Finally, here are some examples involving partitives – ??
Tha a h-aon de na coin aig Màiri Mary has one of the dogs
... a trì deug de na coin ... ... thirteen of the dogs
... fichead de na coin ... ... twenty of the dogs
... ceithir fichead de na coin ... ... eighty of the dogs
... dà fhichead agus a còig de na coin ... ... forty five of the dogs

There are various ways of expressing non-exact, approximate numeric quantities –
mu dheich coin ?? around five dogs
eadar deich agus fichead cù ?? between ten and twenty dogs
ficheadan de choin ?? scores of dogs

Partitive examples –
mu (a) deich de na coin ?? around five of the dogs
eadar a deich agus fichead de na coin ?? between ten and twenty of the dogs
(na) ficheadan de na coin ?? scores of the dogs

Lower-bounded numeric quantities involve an approximate numeric quantity with a minimum number of things –
còrr agus còig coin, barrachd air còig coin more than five dogs
còrr agus a còig de na coin, barrachd air a còig de na coin more than five of the dogs
?? far more than five dogs
?? a few more than five dogs
?? as few as five dogs
?? at least five dogs (co-dhiù còig coin?, còig coin air/aig a’ chàr/chuid as lugha?)

Upper-bounded numeric quantities involve an approximate numeric quantity with a maximum number of things –
?? fewer than five [of the] dogs
?? far fewer than five dogs
?? a few fewer than five dogs
?? as many as five dogs
?? at most five dogs (còig coin air/aig a’ chàr/chuid as fheàrr?)
?? nearly/almost five dogs

p.ed: fractional quantities? half a pound, three-fifths of a gallon etc.
